newsArray.title: Stokes announces shock ODI retirement
newsArray.description: LONDON: England‚Äôs Ben Stokes has announced he will retire from one-day international cricket after Tuesday‚Äôs match against South Africa on his Durham home ground.The all-rounder, 31, said playing three international formats -- Twenty20, 50-over ODIs and Tests -- was now...
newsArray.content: LONDON: England‚Äôs Ben Stokes has announced he will retire from one-day international cricket after Tuesday‚Äôs match against South Africa on his Durham home ground. .ads_between_content{ height:auto; width:auto; clear: both; text-align: center; } .ads_between_content .story_ads{ } /*@media (max-width:600px){ .ads_between_content{ float:none; margin:0px auto; text-align: center; } }*/ The all-rounder, 31, said playing three international formats -- Twenty20, 50-over ODIs and Tests -- was now ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù. Stokes, who captain‚Äôs the England Test team, will take the field at Chester-le-Street against South Africa in the first of three ODIs. Stokes, who has scored 2,919 runs and taken 74 wickets in the format, said in a social media post it had been an ‚Äúincredibly tough decision to make‚Äù. ‚ÄúAs hard as a decision as this was to come to, it‚Äôs not as hard dealing with the fact I can‚Äôt give my teammates 100 percent of myself in this format anymore,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe England shirt deserves nothing less from anyone who wears it. ‚ÄúThree formats are just unsustainable for me now. ‚ÄúNot only do I feel that my body is letting me down because of the schedule and what is expected of us, but I also feel that I am taking the place of another player who can give (captain) Jos (Buttler) and the rest of the team their all.‚Äù Rob Key, managing director of men‚Äôs cricket at the England and Wales Cricket Board, paid tribute to Stokes, saying: ‚ÄúBen has had an incredible international career in ODI cricket, culminating in his match-winning performance at the 2019 ICC Men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup final‚Äù.

newsArray.title: Nawaz relishes 'dream' five-wicket haul
newsArray.description: GALLE: Pakistan all-rounder Mohammad Nawaz said Monday that his maiden five-wicket haul on return to Test cricket was a ‚Äúdream‚Äù performance he aimed to repeat.The 28-year-old Nawaz, who played just three Tests for Pakistan in 2016, impressed with his left-arm spin to dent the Sri...
newsArray.content: GALLE: Pakistan all-rounder Mohammad Nawaz said Monday that his maiden five-wicket haul on return to Test cricket was a ‚Äúdream‚Äù performance he aimed to repeat. .ads_between_content{ height:auto; width:auto; clear: both; text-align: center; } .ads_between_content .story_ads{ } /*@media (max-width:600px){ .ads_between_content{ float:none; margin:0px auto; text-align: center; } }*/ The 28-year-old Nawaz, who played just three Tests for Pakistan in 2016, impressed with his left-arm spin to dent the Sri Lankan top and middle-order in the first match in Galle. He combined with leg-spinner Yasir Shah to reduce Sri Lanka to 267 for eight but the hosts hit back with Dinesh Chandimal‚Äôs unbeaten 86 to lead by 333 at the end of the third day‚Äôs play. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs every bowler‚Äôs dream to get a five-for in Test cricket and the same goes for me,‚Äù Nawaz told reporters. ‚ÄúI am very happy and I will keep working hard and repeat this kind of performance again.‚Äù Nawaz made his debut across formats in 2016 but his five-day career came to a halt after just three Tests against West Indies in the United Arab Emirates. His white-ball reputation has grown, with 19 one-day internationals and 30 Twenty20 matches for the national team, but he insists red-ball cricket is what excites him most. ‚ÄúI kept on playing first-class cricket, obviously played a lot of white-ball international cricket but a Test opportunity didn‚Äôt come my way,‚Äù Nawaz said of his cricketing journey. ‚ÄúFocus was to play red-ball cricket which makes you grow as a player. My 2022 red-ball season at home was good as I made over 700 runs and took 28-29 wickets. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to bowl well on my comeback and hoping to turn up with the bat as well.‚Äù Babar Azam‚Äôs Pakistan will need to bowl out Sri Lanka, who were 329-9 at stumps, on the fourth day and then chase an already challenging-looking total. But Nawaz remains confident of the Pakistan batting that fought back from 87-5 to just four runs short of Sri Lanka‚Äôs 222 in the first innings.

newsArray.title: ‚ÄòCricket is broken‚Äô: Ben Stokes‚Äô shock ODI call exposes ‚Äòcomplete bull***t‚Äô ruining the game
newsArray.description: ‚ÄúCricket is broken,‚Äù Wisden‚Äôs managing editor Ben Gardner declared. It‚Äôs the bitter reality facing the game in the wake of Ben Stokes‚Äô retirement from One Day Internationals.
newsArray.content: ‚ÄúCricket is broken,‚Äù Wisden‚Äôs managing editor Ben Gardner declared. It‚Äôs the bitter reality facing the game in the wake of Ben Stokes‚Äô retirement from One Day Internationals. The England star shocked the sport, and even his teammates, when he revealed he would be giving up the 50-over format to focus on his Test captaincy duties as well as T20 cricket. The news is a bitter blow to England‚Äôs hopes of next year retaining their 2019 ODI World Cup title, in which Stokes was awarded man of the match in the final. But it is more than that. It is a wake-up call for the game‚Äôs administrators around the world. After 50 years, ODI cricket isn‚Äôt what it used to be. And it faces the prospect of losing relevance and its best players, squeezed out of a packed schedule by the traditional and the new ‚Äì Tests and T20s respectively. ‚ÄòCan‚Äôt give my teammates 100%‚Äô: Stokes‚Äô shock retirement call after World Cup heroics The 31-year-old Englishman is one of the finest all-rounders in the game, and ODI cricket has arguably been his best format ‚Äì he has blasted 29,919 runs in 104 games at the impressive average of 39.44 and with a strike rate of 95.26. His 74 wickets with the ball and his elite fielding made him a centrepiece of England‚Äôs team in all three formats ‚Äì but the constant stress of playing in all three forms of the game has clearly taken its toll. But, he wrote, ‚ÄúThree formats are just unsustainable for me now. ‚ÄúI feel that my body is letting me down because of the schedule and what is expected of us.‚Äù In The Telegraph, Nick Hoult said it: ‚Äúfelt like a bombshell but in reality it had a long fuse,‚Äù referencing Stokes‚Äô break from the game at the end of July 2021 for mental health reasons. Hoult added: ‚ÄúDuring his break last year he cut himself off from many of his team-mates and they worried he had fallen out of love with the game. But since taking over from Root as Test captain he has looked like his old self, giving everything to a job he clearly loves.‚Äù The long fuse behind this bombshell is less about Stokes than the game itself ‚Äì and he core problem is not a new one. There is simply too much cricket on the calendar. It is not just unsustainable for Stokes, but for all of cricket. Stokes announcement felt like a carbon copy of Kevin Pietersen‚Äôs own international retirement from white-ball cricket, 10 years ago in June 2012. ‚ÄúAfter a great deal of thought and deliberation, I am announcing my retirement from international one-day cricket.,‚Äù Pietersen said. ‚ÄúWith the intensity of the international schedule and the increasing demands on my body, approaching 32, I think it is the right time to step aside and let the next generation of players come through.‚Äù What was a problem then has devolved into a crisis. In the period June 2022 to March 2023, England is set to play 12 Tests, 18 ODIs, 19 bilateral T20Is and a T20 World Cup ‚Äì over 100 days of men‚Äôs international cricket in all. It is their busiest season ever. And while some of that is due to the inclusion of series that were postponed during the Covid-19 pandemic, it does not change the fundamental problem that faces all three-format players. There is also more domestic T20 cricket than ever, with countries like South Africa debuting a new franchise tournament this summer (so new it doesn‚Äôt even have a name yet!), as well as the ever-increasing number of ICC tournaments like World Cups. England‚Äôs latest cricketing fad, the even-shorter-format The Hundred competition, only adds to the explosive mix. Matt Roller wrote for ESPN Cricinfo : ‚ÄúIn abstract, it should serve as a wake-up call for cricket‚Äôs administrators. One of the sport‚Äôs most recognisable players making himself unavailable for his team‚Äôs defence of their world title in India next year is a damaging moment, one that underlines the extent to which boards have flogged their most valuable assets by cramming series into even the smallest gaps in the schedule.‚Äù As Rory Dollard of PA declared even more simply: ‚ÄúStokes‚Äô ODI retirement ‚Äì complete with very carefully worded criticism of England‚Äôs schedule ‚Äì has to be the tipping point. The fixture list is complete bullsh*t and it‚Äôs wrecking the players and the product. Enough.‚Äù Stokes, for context, has already opted out of the Indian Premier League (T20), as well as The Hundred. His decision, therefore, is clearly not about money ‚Äì though he is in a far more fortunate position in that regard than many players around the world facing the same scheduling crunch. Instead, Stokes made clear his decision was about his love of Test cricket above all. Stokes said: ‚ÄúI will give everything I have to Test cricket, and now, with this decision, I feel I can also give my total commitment to the T20 format.‚Äù ODI series against Proteas cancelled | 00:28 Former England captain Nasser Hussain declared the current schedule ‚Äòmadness‚Äô and delivered praise for Stokes' decision, saying ‚ÄúI respect him immensely.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is disappointing news to say the least but it is a reflection of where the cricketing schedule is at the moment,‚Äù Hussain told Sky Sports. ‚ÄúIt is madness for players. ‚ÄúHalf the reasons [for his retirement] will be physical, and half will be mental, and mental in Ben‚Äôs case is the fact he can‚Äôt do things at 70, 80%. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not just going to be a bit-part player, he has to do it full on and he‚Äôs not willing to do it unless he does it 100%. ‚ÄúIn a way, I respect him immensely for making that decision because that‚Äôs how you want every England cricketer to turn up, giving it everything every single day. ‚ÄúThe issue is not with the ECB as far as Rob Key, the issue is not with Ben Stokes, the issue is with the schedule. ‚ÄúIf the ICC just keep putting on ICC events and individual boards just keep filling the gaps with as much cricket as possible, eventually these cricketers will just say I‚Äôm done, and Ben Stokes is done with one format aged 31, which can‚Äôt be right, really. The schedule needs looking at, it is a bit of a joke at the moment.‚Äù 6 WICKETS! Topley topples India in ODI | 01:26 ODI FUTURE UNDER THREAT In recent years, the rise of T20 cricket and the big-money tournaments like the IPL has led to fears that Test cricket would fall by the wayside, with players opting to become white-ball specialists rather than hone their red-ball craft. In that regard, Stokes' decision to prioritise Test cricket is a win for that format ‚Äì but a major blow to the ODI game. As Former India ODI spinner Pragyan Ojha wrote: ‚ÄúWe were worried about TEST cricket‚Äôs future but the future of ODI looks uncertain! ‚ÄúIn future we may see many cricketers preferring to move away from this format. #SomethingToThinkAbout‚Äù It comes after another Indian international and fellow spinner Ravi Ashwin reveals he turns off the television if ODI cricket is on. No ball causes comical end to T20 final | 02:00 Speaking on the ‚ÄòVaughany and Tuffers Cricket Club‚Äô podcast, Ashwin said: ‚ÄúThe greatest beauty of one-day cricket is ‚Äì sorry, was ‚Äì the ebbs and flows of the game. People used to bide their time and take the game deep. ‚ÄúThe one-day format used to be a format where bowlers had a say. Even me, as a cricket badger and a cricket nut, I switch off the TV after a point and that‚Äôs frankly very scary for the format of the game. ‚ÄúWhen those ebbs and flows go missing, it‚Äôs not cricket anymore. It‚Äôs just an extended form of T20. It‚Äôs a question of relevance and I think ODI cricket needs to find its relevance. It needs to find its spot.‚Äù Finding a place in the calendar is difficult enough, let alone finding -or re-finding - the identity of the format. For some, it already might be too late. BBL 11 Schedule released | 00:52 Simon Briggs wrote for The Telegraph: ‚ÄúWe are witnessing the long, slow death of 50-over cricket ‚Ä¶ credibility is draining from this once vibrant format with each passing day.‚Äù He added: ‚ÄúLike Soda Streams, road atlases and SLR cameras, the traditional one-dayer is now a heritage product of dubious relevance. When the 50-over international turned 50, in January last year, it was the sort of birthday party where everyone crowds around a hospital bed.‚Äù Stokes is not the first player forced into a brutally tough decision about his international career, nor will he be the last. But there can be no doubt that change must take placeto protect players and the game itself.

newsArray.title: Cricket world reacts to sad Ben Stokes announcement: 'Madness'
Ben Stokes announces sudden retirement
newsArray.description: England Test cricket captain Ben Stokes will retire from one-day international cricket after Tuesday‚Äôs match against South Africa in Durham.
newsArray.content: The 31-year-old revealed the shock call on social media, but will continue to play Test cricket and T20 cricket.Watch South Africa‚Äôs Tour of England. Every ODI & T20 Live & On-Demand on Kayo. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now >Stokes has long been an absolute start of the game in all formats of the game but averages 39.44 in ODIs with the bat, compared with 36.16 in Test cricket.With the ball, he‚Äôs less effective in the shorter form, avergaging 41.79 runs per wicket with a strike rate of a wicket every 41.6 balls.But Stokes is a key member of all three formats for England, including his most famous innings where he struck 84 not out to almost single-handedly win the World Cup final for England in controversial 2019 thriller.However, there‚Äôll be no repreat as Stokes revealed via Instagram he was walking away from the 50-over game.‚ÄúI will play my last game for England in ODI cricket on Tuesday in Durham. I have decided to retire from this format. This has been an incredibly tough decision to make. I have loved every minute of playing with my mates for England. We have had an incredible journey on the way,‚Äù Stokes wrote.‚ÄúAs hard as a decision as this was to come to, it‚Äôs not as hard dealing with the fact I can‚Äôt give my teammates 100% of myself in this format anymore. The England shirt deserves nothing less from anyone who wears it.‚ÄúThree formats are just unsustainable for me now. Not only do I feel that my body is letting me down because of the schedule and what is expected of us, but I also feel that I am taking the place of another player who can give Jos and the rest of the team their all. It‚Äôs time for someone else to progress as a cricketer and make incredible memories like I have over the past 11 years.‚ÄúI will give everything I have to Test cricket, and now, with this decision, I feel I can also give my total commitment to the T20 format.‚ÄúI would like to wish Jos Buttler, Matthew Mott, the players and the support staff every success going forward. We have made great strides in white-ball cricket over the past seven years, and the future looks bright.‚ÄúI have loved all 104 games I have played so far, I‚Äôve got one more, and it feels amazing to be playing my last game at my home ground in Durham.‚ÄúAs always, the England fans have always been there for me and will continue to be there. You‚Äôre the best fans in the world. I hope we can win on Tuesday and set the series up nicely against South Africa.‚ÄùThe managing director of England cricket Rob Key paid tribute to the retiring star.‚ÄúI know this must have been a tough decision, but I completely understand why he has reached this conclusion,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure that when we look back on Ben‚Äôs career and see this as one of the reasons he will play 120-plus Tests and help England in T20 matches and World Cups for many years to come.‚ÄúIt is a typically selfless decision that will benefit England long-term.‚ÄùIt was just the start of the tributes for Stokes.Indian star Virat Kohli commented: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the most competitive bloke I‚Äôve ever played against. Respect,‚ÄùPakistan vice captain Shadab Khan posted: ‚ÄúCongratulations on a wonderful ODI career @benstokes38. Best of luck with your Test career and other commitments. ODI cricket will surely miss you.‚ÄùFormer England spinner Monty Panesar wrote: ‚ÄúStokes has made a selfless decision for the benefit of the England team.‚ÄùStokes became England‚Äôs 81st Test captain in April and has already seen some changes.Along with former New Zealand skipper Brendan McCullum as Test coach, England chased down some massive scores, defeating Test World Champions New Zealand 3-0 and the nation‚Äôs biggest ever chase against India earlier this month.It comes amongst a discussion in cricket circles about the schedules being too packed with Test, ODI and T20I cricket as well as domestic competitions and countless T20 competitions around the world.

Sri Lanka might well be at the driver‚Äôs seat after stumps on Day 3 as far as the match situation of the ongoing first Test at Galle is concerned, but Pakistan leg-spinner Yasir‚Ä¶ The post ‚ÄúBall of the century‚Äù: Twitter reactions on Yasir Shah bowling an absolute ripper to dismiss Kusal Mendis during SL vs PAK 1st Test at Galle appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Twitter reactions on Yasir Shah dismissing Kusal Mendis with an absolute peach of a delivery during Sri Lanka‚Äôs second innings at Galle. Sri Lanka might well be at the driver‚Äôs seat after stumps on Day 3 as far as the match situation of the ongoing first Test at Galle is concerned, but Pakistan leg-spinner Yasir Shah was discussed almost the entire day for a particular delivery. On the first delivery of the 56th Over of Sri Lanka‚Äôs second innings, Shah pitched the ball outside the leg-stump, managed to purchase significant turn off the pitch as the ball finally ended up hitting the top of off-stump, with a well-set, yet clueless Kusal Mendis (76) getting completely squared-up and watching the jaw-dropping sight. Fans across the world couldn‚Äôt help but term it the ‚Äòball of the century‚Äô already, with majority of them comparing it with the one that the legendary Shane Warne had bowled to Mike Gatting in the year 1993. Yasir Shah, who is making a return back to Test Cricket after a year, has managed to scalp three Sri Lankan wickets in the innings so far, with the home side clearly on the driver‚Äôs seat at the moment, with a 333-run lead, on a pitch which has assisted the spinners significantly so far. newsArray.title: Ben Stokes‚Äô ODI retirement should be a wake-up call to cricket‚Äôs leaders | Ali Martin
creator: Ali Martin
newsArray.description: From the ECB to ICC, governing bodies need to realise how the packed schedule makes the 50-over game vulnerableIt feels fitting in some ways that during a week that is hotter than Hades ‚Äì when alarm bells about our direction of travel should be ringing even louder ‚Äì Ben Stokes has announced his retirement from one-day international cricket.Yep, the champion all-rounder who powered England to World Cup victory by the barest of margins three summers ago, in front of a packed house at Lord‚Äôs and with the UK‚Äôs largest cricket audience since the heady 2005 Ashes, has decided the 50-over stuff must make way. If not, his schedule as an elite all-format player would become suffocating. The hope now is that this similarly prompts a wake-up call. Continue reading...
newsArray.content: I t feels fitting in some ways that during a week that is hotter than Hades ‚Äì when alarm bells about our direction of travel should be ringing even louder ‚Äì Ben Stokes has announced his retirement from one-day international cricket. Yep, the champion all-rounder who powered England to World Cup victory by the barest of margins three summers ago, in front of a packed house at Lord‚Äôs and with the UK‚Äôs largest cricket audience since the heady 2005 Ashes, has decided the 50-over stuff must make way. If not, his schedule as an elite all-format player would become suffocating. The hope now is that this similarly prompts a wake-up call. Ben Stokes to retire from ODI cricket due to ‚Äòunsustainable‚Äô schedule Read more Rather poetically, he will bid farewell to the format after winning his 105th ODI cap at the Riverside in Chester-le-Street, County Durham on Tuesday. It is the ground that Ged and Deborah Stokes used to drive their restless, sports-mad son to from their home in Cockermouth some three times a week, two hours each way, in an act of selfless parenting that lit the fire for a remarkable sporting career. Ben Stokes, England cricketer and totemic Test captain, powers on, of course. In fact more so, in terms of where, aged 31, he wants to direct his energies. Modern all-format stars do not tend to jack it all in at once anyway, rather strip away that which means least to them and design their latter years weighing up health, wealth and happiness. When they do so it says a bit about the player and plenty about the sport. And Stokes could not have been clearer about the bigger picture here, citing an ‚Äúunsustainable schedule‚Äù and his fear of letting down teammates. For a cricketer paid by one of the boards responsible for this, to be so explicit in pushing back is quite the thing. After all, in practical terms Stokes did n0t have to announce this right now, so deep is his line of credit. He averaged 50 with the bat during Eoin Morgan‚Äôs five-year World Cup project, is a genuine sixth bowler and fields like a demon. Allied with talismanic dressing-room status and, as England‚Äôs highest earner, he could shoulder arms to any series he did not fancy between now and the defence in 2023 and likely still command a spot. Ben Stokes had a disappointing ODI series against India, and has decided the match against South Africa on Tuesday will be his last 50-over game for England. Photograph: Ian Kington/AFP/Getty Images Last week, as well as withdrawing from the upcoming Twenty20 series against South Africa to ready himself for the Test matches that follow, it was announced he would skip the Hundred this summer and his employers simply had to suck it up. No one batted an eyelid, nor would they were his ODIs to become fleeting. But now was the time, like a leader, to take one for the team and give clarity in response to a fixture list that lacks anything of the sort. ‚ÄúI feel that my body is letting me down because of the schedule and what is expected of us,‚Äù he said. This announcement, decided last week but coming during a 48-hour turnaround between ODIs, was as sweetly timed as that famous swept six off Trent Boult at Lord‚Äôs three years ago. Matt Potts set for ODI debut as Mott pleads for patience with Buttler Read more Stokes knows his mind and body have limits. So much so he wisely took a four-month break last summer when bereavement and injury proved an overwhelming mix. Since returning to mental and physical fitness ‚Äì both boxes not fully ticked until the tour of the Caribbean in March, even if he still grimaces in the field at times ‚Äì he has become ever more besotted with Test cricket and taken on tunnel vision with it. ‚ÄúI will give everything I have to Test cricket, and now, with this decision, I feel I can also give my total commitment to the T20 format,‚Äù he said in his statement. The latter‚Äôs appeal is understandable in the modern economic climate but, having passed up the Indian Premier League this year and hinted he will do so again before next summer‚Äôs Ashes assault, it is clear the type of cricket which is calling him. The alliance with the head coach, Brendon McCullum, has also begun in quite astonishing fashion ‚Äì those four spellbinding run chases in a row ‚Äì and one could almost sense during these last three ODIs that this goal is now consuming his every cricketing thought. Put simply, the Test team and winning back the urn from Australia have become an obsession and Stokes is a character who is all-in when hooked. The Spin: sign up and get our weekly cricket email. The fear, of course, is that his broader call for a cleaner schedule falls on deaf ears. The ICC (aka the major boards) is working on a schedule that, while pruning back some ODI cricket over the next five years, features a global men‚Äôs tournament every 12 months. If the 50-over format is on the way out, no one seems to have told the organisers of the 2023, 2027 and 2031 World Cups, or Champions Trophies in 2025 and 2029. Each of the ICC members will also jostle to promote their domestic leagues ‚Äì but stop everything for the two and a half months of the IPL to keep their players happy ‚Äì and somehow attempt to keep touring for their bilateral commitments, too. But on Tuesday, back where it all began for Stokes, it will at least be a chance for the English game to thank the all-rounder for his efforts as a World Cup-winning one-day international star and applaud his burning desire to keep the flame of Test cricket alive.

newsArray.title: Riverside ground chester-le-street pitch report: ENG vs SA 1st ODI 2022 Durham pitch report
creator: Gurpreet Singh
newsArray.description: Riverside ground chester-le-street pitch report: First of the three-match ODI series between England and South Africa to take place tomorrow. After suffering home series defeats in both the White-ball format against India just a couple of days ago, England would now take on the South African challenge right away in the all format series which‚Ä¶ The post Riverside ground chester-le-street pitch report: ENG vs SA 1st ODI 2022 Durham pitch report appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Riverside ground chester-le-street pitch report: First of the three-match ODI series between England and South Africa to take place tomorrow. After suffering home series defeats in both the White-ball format against India just a couple of days ago, England would now take on the South African challenge right away in the all format series which would begin with the first ODI at the Riverside Ground in Chester-le-Street today. The match is of extra significance, as England‚Äôs 2019 World Cup final hero and present Test captain Ben Stokes, just the previous evening came out with a shocking decision to retire from the ODI format with today‚Äôs match at his home ground in Durham set to be his 105th and last 50-Over international game. As for South Africa, who will be led by left-arm spinner Keshav Maharaj, the rainbow nation would play an ODI after almost four months, having previously lost to Bangladesh 1-2 in the three match ODI series in March. While England have won eight out of their last nine ODIs at the Riverside ground, South Africa had won the lone ODI they played here against Sri Lanka by 9 wickets, during the 2019 ICC World Cup. We get candid with #Proteas seamer Lungi Ngidi to chat all things England series, and have a bit of fun to see how good his Geordie accent is ü§£ Watch the full hilarious interview right here üîó https://t.co/u262b9sC8p #ENGvSA #BePartOfIt pic.twitter.com/HVL2poxeai ‚Äî Cricket South Africa (@OfficialCSA) July 17, 2022 The average first innings score in the last five ODIs at the Le-Chester-Street is 268, making it a decent surface to bat on. Traditionally, however, the pitch at this venue in Durham has been a good hunting ground for the fast bowlers, with significant amount of lateral movement in store and carry on offer available on the track. All in all, the Riverside ground pitch is expected to be a fairly balanced one today, with advantages for both batters and the bowlers at different points in the match. Batters are likely to score big after negating the pace threat early on.

newsArray.title: Lendl Simmons retires from international cricket
newsArray.description: Lendl Simmons announced his retirement from international cricket on Friday by handing over a letter to the West Indies cricket board.
newsArray.content: Lendl Simmons announced his retirement from international cricket on Friday by handing over a letter to the West Indies cricket board. The Trinidadian cricketer played 68 ODI and T20 matches. It was in ODI cricket that the world got to see the best of him. He scored 1958 with two centuries and 15 half-centuries against his name and the highest score of 122. In T20 cricket, he amassed 1527 runs with nine fifties and a career strike rate of 120.80. He only played eight Test matches and scored 278 runs in total. Simmons was instrumental for West Indies against India in the semifinals of the 2016 World Cup, scoring an unbeaten 82 off 51 deliveries.Lendl made his T20 debut in 2007 and in 2008, he made his ODI debut vs Pakistan at Faisalabad. He also holds the record of hitting 3rd most sixes in T20 cricket (10) after Gayle and , He also holds the record for most runs in a single edition of CPL. Simmons also played franchise cricket around the world and was pretty successful for teams like Mumbai Indians, Brisbane Heat and Karachi Kings.

Babar Azam vs Virat Kohli centuries: Virat Kohli and Babar Azam total centuries in international Cricket
creator: Gurpreet Singh
newsArray.description: Babar Azam vs Virat Kohli centuries: The mutual respect between these two cricketers had won fans‚Äô hearts from either side of the border. When team India lost the second of the recently concluded three-match ODI series against England at the Lord‚Äôs in London, Virat Kohli was yet again the man and the topic to be‚Ä¶ The post Babar Azam vs Virat Kohli centuries: Virat Kohli and Babar Azam total centuries in international Cricket appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Babar Azam vs Virat Kohli centuries: The mutual respect between these two cricketers had won fans‚Äô hearts from either side of the border. When team India lost the second of the recently concluded three-match ODI series against England at the Lord‚Äôs in London, Virat Kohli was yet again the man and the topic to be discussed and debated, as the 33-year-old headed back towards the dressing room after registering yet another low score in international Cricket, leaving his fans poker-faced with an ever-lasting spell of disappointment. Post midnight, however, Pakistan skipper and one of the best batters across formats at present, Babar Azam, took to his social media handle to lend a shoulder to the champion Indian batter, affirming him that this bad phase would pass soon, while advising him to stay strong. Kohli too, some hours later thanked Babar for his words, while wishing him all the best for his future or perhaps his team‚Äôs ongoing away Test series versus Sri Lanka. While Kohli yet again got dismissed on a low score (17) during the third ODI yesterday at Old Trafford, Babar went on to smash his 7th Test century of the highest order, with the rest of the batting line-up falling like a deck of cards in the first innings of the 1st Test against Sri Lanka at Galle. Babar also, in the process, went on to become the fastest Asian to complete 10,000 international runs, surpassing Kohli himself to the landmark. Virat Kohli had raised his standards so high that now even an average of 36.75 is looking bad. It‚Äôs not that he is terribly out of form but only failing to convert scores into centuries like he used to do in the past. He still has 9 fifties in last 20 innings in ODIs. #EngvInd pic.twitter.com/TLuJCDbrlR ‚Äî Mazher Arshad (@MazherArshad) July 17, 2022 Babar Azam vs Virat Kohli centuries Two modern day legends for sure, but there is no comparison between these two batters in terms of the number of respective individual centuries they have hit in their international career so far. While Virat made his international debut in the year 2008, Babar arrived at the international cricketing scene only in 2015. With consistency being the hallmark of both these right-handed batters, while Virat has a total of 70 centuries (27 ODI and 43 Test) across 463 international matches, Babar has 25 tons (17 ODI, 7 Test, and 1 T20I) under his name in 204* international games for his side. While it remains to be seen how close Babar gets to Virat‚Äôs century count in the coming years, the cricketing fraternity would also keep a keen eye on how Kohli manages to come out of what is perhaps the lowest point in his career so far with the bat. The post Babar Azam vs Virat Kohli centuries: Virat Kohli and Babar Azam total centuries in international Cricket appeared first on The SportsRush.

newsArray.title: England all-rounder Ben Stokes retires from ODI cricket
creator: Telangana Today
newsArray.description: London: Star England all-rounder and 2019 Word Cup final hero Ben Stokes on Monday made a surprise announcement to retire from ODI cricket, saying playing three formats has become ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù for him. The 31-year-old Stokes will play his last ODI against South Africa at his home ground in Durham on Tuesday. Stokes‚Äô ODI career will [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: London: Star England all-rounder and 2019 Word Cup final hero Ben Stokes on Monday made a surprise announcement to retire from ODI cricket, saying playing three formats has become ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù for him. The 31-year-old Stokes will play his last ODI against South Africa at his home ground in Durham on Tuesday. Stokes‚Äô ODI career will forever be remembered for his Player-of-the-Match performance in the World Cup final against New Zealand at the Lord‚Äôs three years ago. His unbeaten 84 helped to send the match into a Super Over as England claimed their first 50-over World Cup title in the most thrilling of circumstances. Stokes, who is England‚Äôs Test captain, has scored 2,919 runs in 104 ODIs and taken 74 wickets. ‚ÄúI will play my last game for England in ODI cricket on Tuesday in Durham. I have decided to retire from this format,‚Äù he said in an England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) statement. ‚ÄúThis has been an incredibly tough decision to make. I have loved every minute of playing with my mates for England. We have had an incredible journey on the way. ‚ÄúAs hard as a decision as this was to come to, it‚Äôs not as hard dealing with the fact I can‚Äôt give my teammates 100% of myself in this format anymore. The England shirt deserves nothing less from anyone who wears it,‚Äù he added.After making his ODI debut against Ireland in 2011, Stokes has emerged as one of England‚Äôs top all-rounders, slamming three centuries. Stokes said he was no longer able to give 100 per cent and that playing three formats was ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù for him now. ‚ÄúThree formats are just unsustainable for me now. Not only do I feel that my body is letting me down because of the schedule and what is expected of us, but I also feel that I am taking the place of another player who can give Jos and the rest of the team their all. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time for someone else to progress as a cricketer and make incredible memories like I have over the past 11 years. ‚ÄúI will give everything I have to Test cricket, and now, with this decision, I feel I can also give my total commitment to the T20 format.‚Äù He wished luck to current white-ball captain Jos Buttler and coach Matthew Mott. ‚ÄúI would like to wish Jos Buttler, Matthew Mott, the players and the support staff every success going forward. We have made great strides in white-ball cricket over the past seven years, and the future looks bright. ‚ÄúI have loved all 104 games I have played so far, I‚Äôve got one more, and it feels amazing to be playing my last game at my home ground in Durham.‚Äù ‚ÄúAs always, the England fans have always been there for me and will continue to be there. You‚Äôre the best fans in the world. I hope we can win on Tuesday and set the series up nicely against South Africa,‚Äù Stokes said.

newsArray.title: Give me 20 minutes with Virat Kohli, I'll help him, says Sunil Gavaskar
creator: Ishka
newsArray.description: Virat Kohli has scored 70 international centuries for IndiaHowever, he has not scored a ton since November 2019Kohli did not score a single fifty in England
newsArray.content: Virat Kohli and Sunil GavaskarVirat Kohli and Sunil GavaskarFormer India captain Sunil Gavaskar has said if he gets "about 20 minutes" with Virat Kohli, he'll be able to help the struggling top-order batsman. Kohli, who has scored over 10,000 international runs for India, has not scored a century in nearly three years. In his last six innings for India, Kohli did not even reach the fifty-run mark. Elaborating on Kohli's issues with the bat, Gavaskar said the nagging line outside the off-stump is troubling the Delhi batsman and the "anxiety" to return to scoring form is making things worse for him. "If I had about 20 minutes with him, I would be able to tell him the things he might have to do. It might help him, I am not saying it will help him but it could, particularly with regards to that off-stump line. Having been an opening batter, having been troubled by that line, there are certain things that you try and do. If I get 20 minutes with him, I might be able to tell him," Gavaskar told India Today. Kohli looked evidently frustrated with all his dismissals during the recently ended limited-overs series in England. He was not a part of the Indian team that is set to travel to the Caribbean for three ODIs and five T20Is.Perspective pic.twitter.com/yrNZ9NVePf‚Äî Virat Kohli (@imVkohli) July 16, 2022 "It goes back to the fact that his first mistake turns out to be his last. Again, just because he is not amongst the runs, there is this anxiety to play at every delivery because that is what batters feel, they have got to score. You look to play at deliveries that you otherwise won't. But he has gotten out to good deliveries as well on this particular tour. "I think we just have to wait and see when he comes back, whether it helps or not helps. As I said, he is allowed a few failures, look at his record for India, 70 international hundreds. I mean, he has got runs in all formats of the game, in all conditions," Gavaskar added. Kohli has recorded 70 international centuries and is one away from equalling Australia great Ricky Ponting. Specifically in Tests, Kohli (27) is fourth in the list of most centuries for India, after Sachin Tendulkar (51), Rahul Dravid (36), and Sunil Gavaskar (35). "Let's be patient, let's not rush things. We, somehow in India, hurry once a player reaches 32, 33, we all the time, look to push him out of the team when they have so much more to contribute. Let's be patient with Kohli as well. All these greats who have served Indian cricket are allowed a few failures."Thank you. Keep shining and rising. Wish you all the best üëè‚Äî Virat Kohli (@imVkohli) July 16, 2022 Kohli is expected to be back for the 2022 Asia Cup tournament, which is scheduled to be played from Aug. 27 to Sept. 11. Originally, Sri Lanka were named hosts of the tournament, which will see the likes of India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan battle out for the trophy. However, due to the economic crisis in Sri Lanka and mass protests across the country, the Secretary of SLC Mohan de Silva earlier stated that the tournament is likely to be hosted in the United Arab Emirates.

England‚Äôs hero from the ICC 2019 World Cup final at the iconic Lord‚Äôs, Ben Stokes, announced his shock retirement from the game‚Äôs 50-Over format on Monday evening, just a‚Ä¶ The post Ben Stokes IPL record: Ben Stokes best score in IPL appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Ben Stokes best score in IPL: Compared to some of his star English peers, the Durham all-rounder is not very rich in experience in the IPL. England‚Äôs hero from the ICC 2019 World Cup final at the iconic Lord‚Äôs, Ben Stokes, announced his shock retirement from the game‚Äôs 50-Over format on Monday evening, just a day after his team‚Äôs 1-2 ODI series loss post the final match at the Old Trafford in Manchester. Expressing an inability to give his teammates 100% of himself in the format, coupled with the ever pressing issue of continued sustenance in all the three formats of the game, the 31-year-old announced that England‚Äôs first ODI versus South Africa tomorrow (Tuesday), in front of his home crowd in Durham would be the last time he‚Äôd represent his country in One-Day internationals. Having missed the entire summer last year while prioritizing his mental health, the Durham all-rounder even decided not to get himself registered for IPL 2022, citing workload management. Having bowled mere three Overs in the three recently concluded ODIs versus India as well, Stokes finally decided to bid adieu to the format, and give it his all in the Tests and the T20Is from here on. pic.twitter.com/xTS5oNfN2j ‚Äî Ben Stokes (@benstokes38) July 18, 2022 ALSO READ: Virat Kohli reacts after Stokes‚Äô retirement from ODI Cricket Ben Stokes best score in IPL As far as his Indian Premier League experience is concerned, Stokes began playing the lucrative league since its 2017 edition, with his first season for the now-defunct Rising Pune Supergiants (RPS). He then played the next four seasons for the Rajasthan Royals (RR), while deciding to withdraw from the league‚Äôs 15th season this year. All in all, Stokes has played a total of 43 IPL matches till date, and has scored 920 runs at an average of 25.55, with the help of two half-centuries and as many centuries. He has also scalped 28 wickets in the league at an average and economy rate of 34.78 and 8.55 respectively. His highest/best score in the IPL came while representing RR in the year 2020, when he played a scintillating knock of 107 off mere 60 deliveries against the Mumbai Indians (MI), to see his side home by 8 wickets, en route the 196-run target. The post Ben Stokes IPL record: Ben Stokes best score in IPL appeared first on The SportsRush.

newsArray.title: West Indies cricketer Denesh Ramdin retires from international cricket
newsArray.description: West Indies cricketer Denesh Ramdin has announced his retirement from international cricket in an Instagram post. Ramdin last played for West Indies in a T20I in December 2019. Ramdin played 74 Tests, 139 ODIs and 71 T20Is. He made his debut in 2005 against Sri Lanka in a test match at Colombo.
